label: PTB-XL
version_info:
PTB-XL v1.0.1 is a maintenance release of the original PTB-XL ECG dataset on PhysioNet.

  • Published: 24 April 2020 on PhysioNet (version 1.0.1).

  • Change log: according to the release notes, v1.0.1 fixes mismatching identifiers between the waveform files and the metadata, while keeping the scientific content (records, annotations, and labels) identical to the initial v1.0.0 release.

  • Scope: no records, labels, or sampling parameters were altered; only metadata/file mappings were corrected.
title: PTB-XL, a large publicly available electrocardiography dataset
description:
Note: This is just an auto-generated example! The information in this document may be inaccurate!

PTB-XL is a large clinical 12-lead electrocardiography (ECG) dataset released on PhysioNet. It contains 21,837 ten-second 12-lead ECG recordings from 18,885 patients, collected in routine clinical practice and curated into a structured research database.

Each ECG recording is annotated with one or more ECG statements following the SCP-ECG standard. In total, the dataset includes 71 ECG statements covering diagnostic, form, and rhythm information (e.g. myocardial infarction, ST/T changes, conduction disturbances, hypertrophy, and normal ECG). Diagnostic statements are organised hierarchically into 5 superclasses and 24 subclasses to support classification at different granularities.

The waveform data are stored in WFDB format at 500 Hz sampling frequency with 16-bit precision and 1 µV/LSB resolution, together with a downsampled 100 Hz version for convenience. Rich accompanying metadata include demographic variables (age, sex, height, weight), infarction characteristics, ECG report text, signal quality indicators, and recommended cross-validation folds. The dataset is designed as a benchmark resource for automatic ECG interpretation and related machine-learning research.
purpose:
Primary Purpose

The PTB-XL dataset was created to address two major limitations in automatic ECG interpretation research: the lack of large, freely accessible clinical ECG datasets and the lack of well-defined benchmark procedures for evaluating algorithms.

Intended Uses

  • Training and benchmarking of machine-learning and deep-learning models for multi-label ECG classification (diagnostic, form, and rhythm statements).

  • Methodological research on robust ECG preprocessing, feature extraction, and representation learning for 12-lead ECG waveforms.

  • Evaluation of clinical decision-support algorithms for cardiovascular disease detection, including myocardial infarction, conduction disturbances, hypertrophy, and ST/T abnormalities.

  • Exploration of dataset characteristics, such as label hierarchies, multi-label co-occurrence patterns, and the impact of signal quality on diagnostic performance.

The dataset is explicitly designed as a reference benchmark for reproducible research, with recommended cross-validation folds to enable fair comparison of algorithms across studies.
disease: Cardiovascular diseases (various cardiac conditions and normal ECGs, including myocardial infarction, ST/T changes, conduction disturbances, hypertrophy, and healthy controls)
study_design: Retrospective observational clinical dataset of routine 10-second 12-lead ECG recordings
patient_criteria:
Inclusion Criteria

  • Patients with at least one standard 12-lead ECG recorded using Schiller AG devices.
  • ECGs recorded between October 1989 and June 1996 and incorporated into the long-term PTB ECG project database.
  • Records for which waveform data and core metadata (e.g. age, sex, recording date) were available and passed technical quality checks.
  • ECGs that could be annotated with one or more SCP-ECG statements and whose metadata could be pseudonymised and de-identified according to the ethics approval.

Exclusion Criteria

  • ECG recordings with missing or corrupted waveform files or essential metadata that prevented inclusion in the curated database.
  • Records failing technical validation (e.g. unusable signal quality) during the PTB curation process.
  • Any records that could not be sufficiently anonymised to comply with the ethics committee’s requirements for open-access publication.
target_variables:
The dataset supports a variety of prediction targets and downstream variables. Key groups include:

  • ECG diagnostic labels
    • Multi-label SCP-ECG statements (71 total), covering:
      • Diagnostic statements (e.g. myocardial infarction subclasses, hypertrophy, conduction disturbances, ST/T changes).
      • Form statements (morphological characteristics).
      • Rhythm statements (e.g. sinus rhythm, arrhythmias).
    • Diagnostic superclasses (5 main groups): Normal ECG (NORM), Myocardial Infarction (MI), ST/T Change (STTC), Conduction Disturbance (CD), and Hypertrophy (HYP).
    • Diagnostic subclasses (24 finer-grained categories) for more detailed classification.
  • Demographic and clinical metadata
    • Age (0–95 years, with top-coded ages > 89), sex, height, weight.
    • Infarction-related fields (e.g. infarction stadium 1/2) and heart axis, where available.
  • Signal quality and technical variables
    • Static and burst noise indicators, baseline drift, electrode problems, presence of extra beats, pacemaker indicators, and other artefact markers.
  • Benchmarking structure
    • Recommended 10-fold cross-validation assignments (stratified by label and patient) with suggested train/validation/test splits.
time_zero:
There is no single clinical “index date” in PTB-XL; instead, the dataset is organised at the level of individual ECG recordings.

  • For each record, time zero corresponds to the start of the 10-second 12-lead ECG acquisition, as encoded in the metadata (recording_date) and the waveform files.
  • Analyses typically treat each 10-second ECG as an independent sample anchored to its recording time, rather than modelling long-term patient trajectories.
  • Recording dates are per-patient shifted by a random offset to support de-identification, so time zero is suitable for within-record and within-dataset analysis but not for linking back to real-world calendar dates.
acquisition_methods:
Data Acquisition

  • Devices and leads: ECGs were recorded with devices from Schiller AG. Each record contains the standard 12 leads (I, II, III, aVL, aVR, aVF, V1–V6) with reference electrodes on the right arm.
  • Recording protocol: Each ECG is 10 seconds long. The original clinical recordings were stored in a proprietary compressed format and later converted into research-grade waveform files.
  • Metadata collection: For each ECG, general metadata such as age, sex, height, weight, recording date, recording site, device and nurse were stored in a structured database.
  • Clinical reporting and ECG statements: Each record was associated with a free-text report (generated either by a cardiologist or by the ECG device’s automatic interpretation). These reports were converted into a structured set of SCP-ECG statements (scp_codes), including diagnostic, form, and rhythm annotations. For many records, additional fields such as heart axis and infarction stadium were extracted.
  • Annotation workflow:
    • ECGs were annotated by up to two cardiologists, allowing for multi-label diagnostic statements.
    • A technical expert validated all waveforms with a focus on signal characteristics and artefacts.

Data Preprocessing and File Organisation

  • Waveform format: Signals are stored in WFDB format with 16-bit precision and a resolution of 1 µV/LSB.
  • Sampling frequency:
    • records500/: full-resolution ECGs at 500 Hz.
    • records100/: downsampled ECGs at 100 Hz for convenience.
  • Metadata files:
    • ptbxl_database.csv: main metadata table (one row per ECG; identifiers, demographics, ECG statements, signal quality variables, and cross-validation folds).
    • scp_statements.csv: definition of all SCP-ECG statements, including mappings to external coding schemes (AHA, CDISC, DICOM, etc.), statement categories, and hierarchical diagnostic classes/subclasses.
  • Train–test splits: Recommended 10-fold stratified splits (strat_fold) ensure that all records from a given patient are assigned to a single fold. Folds 1–8 are intended for training, fold 9 for validation, and fold 10 for testing.
healthcare_setting: Secondary/tertiary care clinical cardiology settings in Germany (routine clinical 12-lead ECG recordings curated by PTB)
privacy_compliance:
De-identification and Anonymisation

  • Personal identifiers: Direct identifiers (e.g. names, addresses, hospital identifiers, staff names) were removed or pseudonymised. Patients and ECGs are referenced only via patient_id and ecg_id codes.

  • Dates: All ECG recording dates were shifted by a random offset per patient, preserving internal temporal relationships while breaking links to real-world calendar dates.

  • Ages: To comply with HIPAA-style de-identification, ages greater than 89 years are top-coded and appear in the range around 300 years.

  • Clinical metadata: Only variables required for research use (demographics, infarction characteristics, signal quality descriptors, etc.) are retained; free-text reports are stored in a controlled form and sensitive content is minimised.

Regulatory and Policy Alignment

  • The Institutional Ethics Committee approved publication of the anonymous ECG database in an open-access repository (approval PTB-2020-1).

  • The de-identification procedures (pseudonymisation, date shifting, age top-coding, removal of direct identifiers) are designed to align with HIPAA de-identification concepts and typical GDPR requirements for anonymised research data.

  • The released data are distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International licence (CC BY 4.0), which governs reuse but does not affect privacy safeguards applied to the source data.

ethics_approval.details:
The underlying ECG data were collected as part of routine clinical care and later curated into the PTB-XL research database. The Institutional Ethics Committee of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) approved the publication of the anonymous ECG database as an open-access resource under the reference PTB-2020-1.

The approval covers the release of de-identified waveform data and associated metadata on PhysioNet, subject to strict de-identification procedures (pseudonymisation, date shifting, age top-coding, and removal of direct identifiers). No interventions were performed beyond routine clinical care, and the dataset is used exclusively for secondary research on ECG analysis and algorithm development.

patient_consent.details:
The dataset is composed of retrospective clinical ECG recordings collected over 1989–1996. For the public release on PhysioNet, the Institutional Ethics Committee approved the open-access publication of anonymous data (approval PTB-2020-1), which effectively constitutes a waiver of individual informed consent for the historical recordings.

Patients are therefore not individually re-contacted for consent; instead, anonymisation and ethics approval form the legal and ethical basis for reuse. Users of PTB-XL are expected to comply with the PhysioNet licence terms and any additional institutional or jurisdictional requirements that apply to secondary use of de-identified clinical data.
